The C Programming Language


  • Hello World!
  • Variables
  • Data Types
  • Structs
  • Constants

Hello World!

As is tradition, we will begin by writing the "Hello World!" program. The C code is written below.

int main() { printf("Hello World!"); }

To compile the code, use the gcc compiler to create the executable a.out.

gcc hello_world.c

Then run the a.out executable to see your computer say hi!

Variables

We can store data in our program using variables. We use symbolic names to keep track of our variables. For example:

int cash=-10;

Variable names must follow certain rules. In the C programming language, variables must always begin with either a letter or an underscore, and variable names must always be composed of only letters, numbers, and underscores.

Data Types

C uses a number of data types. Some of the more common one are:

  • int- stores a range of integers.
  • long- stores a range of integers equal or greater than the int data type.
  • float- stores decimal numbers.
  • double- stores decimal numbers with double precision.
  • char- stores characters.

When we declare a new variable, we specify the data type before the variable name as shown below.

char alpha;

Structs

We can group several different variables together to form a struct. Structs are objects that can be used to represent a grouping of several different data types.

struct a{int b; int c; char d;};

Constants

We can modify variables using the const keyword.

const int x=5;

x can now not be changed from its initial value of 5.
